There are several examples of scandals and controversies among the priests of the Osirian cult in ancient Egypt. These controversies often involved accusations of corruption, fraud, or other immoral behavior. Here are some examples:

1. Destruction of religious texts: During the reign of the pharaoh Ramesses III (1186-1155 BCE), there was a trial of several members of the priesthood of Amun, who were accused of conspiring to destroy or alter religious texts in order to manipulate religious office appointments. While these texts may not have been directly related to the Osirian cult, the trial was part of a broader campaign by the pharaoh to root out corruption and abuses among the priesthoods.

2. Bribery and nepotism: In one famous example, the High Priest of Amun, Menkheperre, was accused of using his influence to secure appointments for his family members within the priesthood. These accusations were made in a letter written by one of his accusers, who had been passed over for a position he believed he deserved. Similar accusations were made against other priests in different periods.

3. Failure to maintain temples: There are also examples of priests being accused of neglecting their duties to maintain and upkeep the temples associated with the Osirian cult. For example, during the 18th Dynasty, the pharaoh Hatshepsut complained that some priests were failing to keep the temple of Amun in good condition and not providing adequate offerings to the gods.

4. Involvement in politics: Some priests of the Osirian cult also became involved in political intrigues, which could lead to scandals. For example, in the 21st Dynasty, the High Priest of Amun, Amenhotep, was accused of conspiring to overthrow the pharaoh. He was eventually executed for his role in the plot.

Overall, while the priesthoods associated with the Osirian cult were generally well-respected and powerful, there were also examples of scandals and controversies involving some priests. These controversies often reflected broader issues in Egyptian society, such as corruption or political intrigue.
